TL;DR - Worth it for fans of arena fighters and Dragon Ball. Gameplay feels good and it features many (but not all) fan favorite characters. Worth it on a decent discount. 

Now, here's the thing - I've been a fan of Budokai games since the PS2 era, and they give some nice memories. 

Sparking Zero is a modernized Tenkaichi (Sparking) game, with updated graphics and combat mechanics. 

The combat feels fluid, with a few game patches it has gotten a lot more balanced so it can be good fun for competitive players. 

It can also be played P1vP2 locally, so the level of fun pretty much depends on you. 

The soundtrack is decent but the anime tracks that you have to purchase individually if you don't buy the Deluxe+ are extremely overpriced.

Now the mixed : Online play is connection and FPS dependent, so if your opponent has 40 FPS and you 60 your game will feel like a slow-motion movie. The story mode is quite basic and some characters don't even have complete sagas for them (e.g. Vegeta doesn't even explore most of the Super anime), and there aren't that many cutscenes - you might get some title cards and some overlaid text - the Narrator is also not there most of the time.

You can create Custom Battles as well, but it takes a lot of effort and it might be for you, it wasn't really for me.

So the single player modes are kinda lacking, and the main focus is on multiplayer/online play.

And the main problem of the game is exactly there: the competitive community. People will try to do anything for a win of imaginary worthless online points : exploit the game, lag-switch, disconnect so that they don't lose points.. Unless you can handle such levels of toxicity and "stress", I recommend playing with friends/family for fun. Every online game mode of the game (even Player/Unranked match) is extremely toxic 90% of the time.

So why do I recommend it?

At the end of the day it's Dragon Ball - a great nostalgic feeling comes when I start it up, it looks good, runs good and even against the CPU it can be a fun challenge. On PC you also get the option to add mods to further increase your enjoyment.

It could've been great, ended up being good. Good enough, I guess.

FOR STEAM DECK USERS:

Please read this carefully. Dragon Ball Sparking Zero is perfectly playable on a Steam Deck with some caveats:
- we'll be setting it at 40FPS;
- no online play.
If you don't mind it, then let's get to it.

So the game runs at 60FPS and the frame drops are frequent and very evident. If we lock the game at 40FPS, it runs much smoother. I did it through this YouTube video:
https://youtu.be/FS-axZmssBE?si=0iGASNGVgFyUKZZG

These are my graphics settings on the actual game:
Resolution scale: 85
V-sync: Off
Anti-aliasing quality: Medium
Shadow quality: Low
Texture quality: Medium
Post-processing quality: Low
Effect quality: Low
Depth of field: Low 
LOD quality: Medium
Grass quality: Low
Motion blur quality: Low
Camera shake: Low
Destruction effect quality: Low

Now, for the actual review:
The game is pure cinema. It is beautiful and the action is exactly what a Dragon Ball game should be. Gameplay is awesome and it expanded on BT3, which is great in my opinion. However:
- the content is short, as the game seems to be focused more on online gameplay, which is a shame;
- only 8 fighters per tournament (excluding teams);
- cutscenes in the "story" content are ugly, in my opinion - the way the characters move is off (reminds me of Sonic 06);
- what if scenarios are actually interesting.

The first 10-15h were so exciting to me. But now I'm bored of the game. It lacks single-player content and for that reason I don't think the game can be higher than maybe a 7/10. It's a difficult one to rate for nostalgia reasons.

Full disclosure, I'm terrible at fighting games so I got my ass beat a lot and my only real exposure to Dragon Ball was the Abridged series by Team 4 Star. Having said that, I still had fun with all the different campaigns aside from the difficulty spikes that popped up every now and then.

Would've liked a campaign for Cell though, or Trunks missions during the Cell Arc. Bit of a missed opportunity on both of those accounts tbh.

I don't regret pre-ordering the ultimate edition of this game, as I genuinely had fun within the first week of its release. I truly believed, at the time, that we had a dragon ball game that would last us a generation, and be a milestone within the dragon ball community. 

I, along with many other people who believed in this game, turned out to be wrong. I cannot recommend this game because its developers do not believe in it, because simple tweaks and additions, like costume changes and quality of life updates that would make the custom battle maker actually usable, are still not added even a whole year after release. Instead, what we have gotten since then are DLC characters, and not even all of them either.

It is not worth the money, even on sale, and if the people who made this game don't wanna put in time and effort into making it better, then why the hell should anybody do the same when it comes to playing it? 

This will not go down as a generational DLC game, it will go down as a generational disappointment, and I am tragically glad that Akira Toriyama is not alive to see what his IP has turned into.

This game is fun until you realize how unfinished it is

Combat:
It's been a year and this game is still buggy. The game has many great mechanics, but I can't name a single one that works as it should. The controls are clunky and limit the player artificially. You even have to use a workaround to do an emote. The game punishes you for trying do develop your own playstyle. And the playerbase is the worst I've met so far. It's gotten better with recent patches, but as soon as you leave B rank, players still do everything but learn the game to get their win or rage quit if they don't

Graphics:
The best any Dragon Ball game ever looked. But some animations aren't finished, which makes this game look inconsistent. Many Super Attacks have weird pacing. And there's lack of detail in some areas. For example the particles on Genkidama are too few and move incorrectly. And many attacks lack impact

Modes:
World Tournament mode isn't finished. Characters ringout themselves when too close to the ground. The game added team tournaments with individual eliminations.. but characters don't get eliminated from the team. Overall tournaments are too small. This mode might be great if it ever gets fixed. Being able to customize tournaments is a  great addition

Custom Battle lacks.. customization. The event system is limited. This mode really needs to be extended

Legendary Warrior Face-Off: either make this mode available permanently as a Bonus Battle or completely remove it from the game

The Tag Team mode from the Switch version hasn't been ported to the other platforms

Story mode is fine. It's not great, but it has its moments. Still better than BT3's story mode. It's not the mode where you spend most of your time. The way it's implemented makes sense for Custom Battle mode

Characters:
Most characters move the same, have the same ki blasts and often even reuse animations. Some movesets are incomplete. At launch, the animation of DBZ Broly's grab super was clunky. Instead of fixing the animation, the devs just moved the camera so you can't see it. Goku is the only character who has [his version of] Roasie's Super Attack. She a generic Super, the same Super again with a different cutscene and a reused Ultimate

Regardless some characters are very fun to play as. Roshi, Goku (except Daima Mini), Mr. Satan, Majin Vegeta, DBZ Frieza, Dyspo, DBSH Piccolo, Androids and most 2-3DP characters actually play different than most characters. You just won't see much of it because of the player base

Offline content:
lol

Conclusion:
Only buy if you're a hardcore Tenkaichi fan or the game is on 50% discount or more. Or wait another 1-2 years until the game is finished. Most of the patches so far were great

And don't buy the Ultimate Edition. It's literally just what it says. The Super Attack isn't even good

Honestly around launch and for a while after the game was fun, while not perfect it had potential that needed fostering. A patch or two fixing a fair few complaints while dozens others lie untouched. The customization is lacking, the story while fun at times, just isn't all that fun or engaging. 

Player counts are low, as of writing is at about ~650 players. You're lucky to see over 1k on the weekend, and all of those that remain generally have the game down pat. So even when you finally get a match, chances are that if you're new to the game you're going to get obliterated. While common for fighting games this is not FighterZ, this is a party fighting game best played with friends either locally or in a call together. This game is fun until you realize how unfinished it is

Combat:
It's been a year and this game is still buggy. The game has many great mechanics, but I can't name a single one that works as it should. The controls are clunky and limit the player artificially. You even have to use a workaround to do an emote. The game punishes you for trying do develop your own playstyle. And the playerbase is the worst I've met so far. It's gotten better with recent patches, but as soon as you leave B rank, players still do everything but learn the game to get their win or rage quit if they don't

Graphics:
The best any Dragon Ball game ever looked. But some animations aren't finished, which makes this game look inconsistent. Many Super Attacks have weird pacing. And there's lack of detail in some areas. For example the particles on Genkidama are too few and move incorrectly. And many attacks lack impact

Modes:
World Tournament mode isn't finished. Characters ringout themselves when too close to the ground. The game added team tournaments with individual eliminations.. but characters don't get eliminated from the team. Overall tournaments are too small. This mode might be great if it ever gets fixed. Being able to customize tournaments is a  great addition

Custom Battle lacks.. customization. The event system is limited. This mode really needs to be extended

Legendary Warrior Face-Off: either make this mode available permanently as a Bonus Battle or completely remove it from the game

The Tag Team mode from the Switch version hasn't been ported to the other platforms

Story mode is fine. It's not great, but it has its moments. Still better than BT3's story mode. It's not the mode where you spend most of your time. The way it's implemented makes sense for Custom Battle mode

Characters:
Most characters move the same, have the same ki blasts and often even reuse animations. Some movesets are incomplete. At launch, the animation of DBZ Broly's grab super was clunky. Instead of fixing the animation, the devs just moved the camera so you can't see it. Goku is the only character who has [his version of] Roasie's Super Attack. She a generic Super, the same Super again with a different cutscene and a reused Ultimate

Regardless some characters are very fun to play as. Roshi, Goku (except Daima Mini), Mr. Satan, Majin Vegeta, DBZ Frieza, Dyspo, DBSH Piccolo, Androids and most 2-3DP characters actually play different than most characters. You just won't see much of it because of the player base

Offline content:
lol

Conclusion:
Only buy if you're a hardcore Tenkaichi fan or the game is on 50% discount or more. Or wait another 1-2 years until the game is finished. Most of the patches so far were great

And don't buy the Ultimate Edition. It's literally just what it says. The Super Attack isn't even good

As far as Dragon Ball games go, I would say this one is middle of the pack at best. It's got stunning visuals and a large roster, but the combat feels less interesting than other iterations of DB games. About half the super attacks in the game have terrible homing and the collision in many of the arenas leads to immersion breaking moments in fights and further issues with the already bad homing attacks. A large complaint I saw about this game upon its release was its high difficulty, but I felt it was a bit too easy as a seasoned fighting game player. If you've ever played a DB 3D game before, this one won't feel difficult at all. 

The game gives you the ability to play through story moments as antagonists, but this experience does not lead to new branching storylines and really isn't anything outside of what you could achieve by just setting up a custom battle playing as the antagonist in the first place. 

The big thing that drives this game home from my earlier "middle of the pack" sentiment to clicking "not recommend" out of the two options is the price. I got this game on sale, but even so, it does not feel worth the money. The story is rushed, skipping over several parts in each arc for an unknown reason. Not fighting every member of the Ginyu Force is a forgiveable exclusion, they are filler sandbags, but not fighting every phase of Frieza is an injustice to the Namek arc.

Overall, I would recommend Xenoverse 2 over this game. Sparking Zero is just that: sparking visuals, zero recommendation. Maybe I'll just use it as a simulator of different characters battling since it is fun to watch, but not to play.

Please, don't buy. By the time that you've finished the story mode the game feels like a fighting sandbox with barely any replayability, not to mention that the game is somehow still unfinished. A severe lack of maps, cosmetics, story and game modes has led to me feeling very dissappointed in the fact that I spent over 100 dollars on this.

After completing the story, the only game mode that exists outside of single battles, online battles and tournaments is cutsom battles. You can basically create your own scenarios for battles and share them with other players. Here are the problems with it: it is way too fucking difficult to use (searching through 1000s of dialogue options to find one you like because you can only filter, but that barely helps) and the things you create immediately get lost in the crowd of things others have created because there are practically no options for searching.

Quickly gonna mention the performance issues: only play if you have a newer PC or something, because I'm using a computer I got around 2018 and the lag is unbearable.

All in all, you may have a fun time for the first 50-100 hours (like me) but there's no reason to spend 100 dollars on this. It's a game that was rushed and released for profit, even if it seemed like a love letter at first.
